abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the State Pension Systems
            Reform Technical Assistance Project (PARSE4P) for Brazil
            were as follows: the outcome was highly satisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was high, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: PARSEP (I) is an excellent endorsement of the old
            LIL model, one which allowed the flexibility to learn by
            doing. Its success in fact raises questions as to the new
            LIL format, actions based on a driving hypothesis, because
            had it followed that model, it would not have achieved as
            much as it did. Fundamental policy change may have to build
            on initial institutional strengthening. Reforms take time,
            but also that a reform which has languished apparently
            unproductively for a few years may suddenly pick up speed.
            From the beginning this project emphasized information, and
            the emphasis only grew over the course of implementation.
            Design shortcomings (whether as erroneously proposed
            solutions or failures to anticipate new openings) should be
            given a chance for rectification in project implementation.
            This was the advantage of the old-style LIL.
